title.narrative: Strengthening the capacity of developing countries to mitigate the impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic through appropriate technology transfer from Japan

description.narrative: The COVID-19 pandemic is primarily a global health crisis, but it also has far-reaching economic consequences. Worldwide, it is already disrupting millions of people’s livelihoods, with disproportionate impact on the poor, thereby jeopardizing the successful achievement of the United Nations Sustainable Development Agenda 2030. In order to meet an unprecedented global challenge of the COVID-19 pandemic, there is a high demand for the international community to provide an agile and suitable response towards the socio-economic impacts worldwide, in particular concerning fragile health infrastructures in developing and emerging countries. Recognizing this challenge and the need for international commitment and solidarity, the Government of Japan (GoJ) is providing the supplementary budget to UNIDO in order to show their responsibility to meet an increasing demand for emergency support. In addition, the GoJ recognizes the need to support Japanese technology providers, especially small and medium enterprises (SMEs), which own their technical know-how but have limited channels to meet the global demand. Therefore, the project aims: (1) to support developing and emerging countries to improve health, sanitary and hygiene environment to fight against COVID-19 and other infectious diseases through technology transfer; (2) to leverage capacity of Japanese enterprises, especially SMEs, to meet the demand in this emergent situation; and (3) to demonstrate UNIDO’s commitment to the GoJ to support their efforts for the international cooperation to fight against COVID-19 crisis. Since UNIDO ITPO Tokyo has a profound experience in promoting sustainable and innovative technologies and know-how owned by Japanese companies to developing countries, UNIDO ITPO Tokyo plays a role to facilitate technology transfer, backstopped by ITPO Coordinator as the Project Manager at UNIDO HQs. The project complements its current project (SAP ID 160239) to promote applicable technologies through demonstration and technology transfer, including the “Human Health Technologies”, registered in the UNIDO ITPO Tokyo's Sustainable Technologies Promotion Platform (STePP).

title.narrative: Response to the COVID-19 crisis and recovery of the tourism sector in Cabo Verde

description.narrative:
The Government of Cabo Verde has identified a range of measures that will offer the means to tourism-sector stakeholders to not only recover from the impact of COVID-19 but also make it more competitive in the medium-to-long term.
The overall objective (impact-level) of the project is to safeguard the overall socio-economic fabric of Cabo Verde during and after the COVID-19 crisis.
The Specific objective is to mitigate the socioeconomic impact of COVID-19 pandemic for the most vulnerable economic actors (informal and REMPE workers) and to support the recovery of the tourism sector.
Through a partnership with UNIDO, a simplified certification scheme for quality assurance will be implemented to remove access barriers to trade and market entry for MSMEs within tourism sector value chains.
This project will be implemented within the framework of Addendum 1 of the Contribution Agreement FED/2019/413-300 signed between EU and UNDP on 18 December 2020

This intervention seeks to address the supply shortages of masks accentuated by import restrictions (especially as the country is the midst of confinement), as well as the risk of business closure (especially SMEs) and of increased unemployment (especially women) deriving from the economic slowdown.

title.narrative: Supporting the mitigation of the COVID-19 impact on the dairy sector#s food security and safety in Sudan

description.narrative:
This project document outlines UNIDO’s proposed approach to the International Islamic Trade Finance Corporation’s Recovery Response Program (RRP). Discussions between ITFC and UNIDO highlighted the synergies between the RRP and UNIDO’s post-conflict programme. The Ministry of Industry and Trade of Sudan requested UNIDO’s technical assistance to support the dairy sector value chains, vegetables & fruits processing, and related value addition as well as the meat sector value chains. Amid consultations with the Ministry, priority for an immediate project intervention on the dairy sector was emphasized.
The project therefore aims to: i) provide technical assistance on dairy food safety systems and production practices to mitigate the impact of COVID19 pandemic, ii) contribute direct financial support to selected dairy enterprises to resume production and iii) set up the governance structure for the Entrepreneurial Development Committee (EDC) in Khartoum focusing on building and strengthening the entrepreneurial and technical skills of business ideas promoters as well as established entrepreneurs, to start or expand their own MSMEs.
The proposed project is a 6 months pilot that will, in addition to the direct technical and financial interventions, conduct financial and economic assessments on the dairy sector in Sudan and develop a comprehensive sector recovery plan with set of recommendations for improving the dairy industry to create more jobs and increase productivity, facilitate financial access, and help expand the sector through a scale-up project beyond 2020.

title.narrative: Preparatory process for the Centre for Renewable Energy and Energy Efficiency for Central Africa

description.narrative:
Under the umbrella of the Global Network of Regional Sustainable Energy Centres (GN-SEC) program, The United Nations Industrial Development Organisation (UNIDO) and the Economic Community of Central African States (ECCAS) are partnering on the establishment of the Centre for Renewable Energy and Energy Efficiency for Central Africa (CEREEAC).
The partnership is based on an official request submitted by the ECCAS Secretariat to the UNIDO Director-General in February 2020. In an official response letter the UNIDO Director-General pledged support for the process through the GN-SEC program. With the creation of the CEREEAC, the GN-SEC will cover all parts of Africa. The centre can closely cooperate with RCREEE, ECREEE, SACREEE and EACREEE on intercontinental issues under the African Union (AU) framework. GN-SEC examples have proven, that the strengthening of regional capacities through a dedicated institution can help to accelerate national clean energy efforts and contribute to better coordination, coherence, equal progress, as well as economies of scale. As other partners, UNIDO has the opportunity to make use of the created regional/continental infrastructure for its technical services, as well as its convening and normative functions.
Currently, UNIDO and ECCAS are implementing a consultative preparatory process, which determines the added value, feasibility as well as the technical and institutional design of the centre. A needs and feasibility assessment and a project document on the first operational phase are under development. Consultants were contracted and a comprehensive stakeholder consultation is underway. A GN-SEC web-page was established under: http://cereeac.gn-sec.net.
In line with the project document, the process has been supported through donor funds of the GN-SEC global project (project ID 180301). Since the CEREEAC establishment becomes now more concrete, a formal UNIDO project request is submitted. Between UNIDO and ECCAS there is agreement to validate the CEREEAC project document in the 2nd quarter of 2020 on the margins of a meeting of Ministers of Energy. The meeting will be organised in partnership with the International Renewable Energy Agency (IRENA) and the Africa-EU Energy Partnership (AEEP).
Based on the received comments during the validation workshop, the project document will be finalised. It is intended to sign a first funding agreement in conjunction with Vienna Energy Forum (VEF) in July 2021. A competitive selection process of the host country of the CEREEAC Secretariat will be implemented by ECCAS in partnership with UNIDO. Several ECCAS countries indicated interest to host the centre, incl. the Republic of Congo, Cameroon and Sao Tome and Principe.
From the very beginning, the centre will lie in the ownership of ECCAS. It will operate with a small initial staff base and a network of national focal institutions. In line with the GN-SEC twinning (peer to peer learning) model, UNIDO will support the centre throughout its first operational phase by providing services related to mentoring, institution building and technical program development.
The creation of CEREEAC is fully in line with regional policies of ECCAS and CEMAC. The centre is part of the ECCAS efforts to establish an integrated and inclusive single market for products and services in traditional and emerging sectors, including sustainable energy and cleantech. The establishment of the centre will complement and significantly contribute to the existing efforts of ECCAS to promote energy and transport connectivity in the region. Moreover, it is a demonstrated response of ECCAS to the post COVID-19 green recovery paradigm in international cooperation.
The CEREEAC will contribute to the achievement of the ECCAS Green Economy and Renewable Energy Vision, the ECCAS Vision 2025, as well as the CEMAC White Paper and Energy Policy 2035. Moreover, it contributes to the new ECCAS Industrialisation and Economic Diversification Strategy, which aims to diversify the economies and reduce the dependency on the export of raw materials and primary products (incl. fossil fuels). The temporary oil price drop caused by the COVID-19 crisis has demonstrated the risk of being primarily dependent on the export of oil products.
The CEREEAC project is fully in line with the provided UNIDO support to the Third Industrial Development Decade for Africa (IDDA III) and the African Continental Freetrade Area (AfCFTA). Together, the African GN-SECs can contribute to the implementation of the AfCFTA with regard to harmonised sustainable energy product and service markets. In line with the AfCFTA, the objective is to keep the value chains of sustainable energy manufacturing and servicing as much as possible within the region.
The CEREEAC project has strong links to the other ongoing GN-SEC projects in Africa (e.g. ECREEE, SACREEE, EACREEE, EELA), as well as the GEF funded UNIDO energy portfolio in Central Africa (e.g. Republic of Congo, Sao Tome and Principe, Cameroon). There are particular links to the project (ID 190379), aiming at the establishment of the Oyo Centre of Excellence for Renewable Energy and Energy Efficiency in the Republic of Congo. The centre might candidate for the hosting of the regional ECCAS component.

title.narrative: Enhancing the provision of personal protective equipment in Africa: Strengthening the resilience of the industrial and healthcare sectors to COVID-19 and future pandemics

description.narrative: The project objectives are the improved supply of quality-assured, locally manufactured PPE (personal protective equipment), hand sanitizer and disinfectants to reduce the incidence of COVID-19 transmission in Africa and improve the response capacity of national healthcare systems on the continent (medical equipment, specifically ventilators and related equipment, may also be included dependent on inception phase outcomes). The objectives are achieved through the strengthening of both healthcare systems and infrastructure on the continent, as well as strengthening of manufacturers and related value chains such that production and related capabilities are increased. Alongside this, the project aims to reduce the socioeconomic impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on African countries through both securing existing employment positions the relevant manufacturing and related industries, as well as creating additional employment opportunities through industrial expansion. The project outcome is an increased ability for African countries to meet their needs for COVID-19 PPE, sanitizer and disinfectant supply, through local sourcing of quality-assured products, and consequent reduced reliance on imports. Alongside this, the strengthened manufacturing industry will improve employment prospects, reducing the direct economic impact of the COVID-19 crisis on individuals, countries and the continent as a whole. The project will apply a series of modular service packages in order to achieve its objectives. These include development and dissemination of guidelines covering PPE requirements for both the public and private sectors, including national regulatory bodies and industry, as well as providing training and strategic support services to companies moving into and/or increasing PPE, sanitizer and disinfectant production. Alongside this, the provision of quality and standards training and support to industry and relevant certifying bodies will assure the manufacture of effective, quality assured products meeting certification requirements. The project will be implemented in a series of countries across the continent, to ensure broad regional coverage, namely Egypt (North Africa), Ethiopia and Kenya (East Africa), South Africa (South Africa), Senegal (West Africa). The service packages will be designed such that they can both be readily and efficiently rolled out into each country, whilst allowing tailoring to meet individual country requirements. There will be an initial assessment and analytical phase in each country followed by implementation of the required service packages. The service packages will be designed to allow efficient and cost effective expansion to further territories, beyond the five countries listed above, when opportunities arise for project expansion and associated additional funding has been mobilised.

title.narrative: Emergency response assistance to the outbreak of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) in the Islamic Republic of Iran

description.narrative:
In early 2020, the outbreak of new coronavirus (COVID-19) began to spread around the world, and the number of confirmed cases and deaths increased substantially every day, and most of countries faced a very serious situation to fight against the COVID-19. It was declared as a Public Health Emergency of International Concern by WHO on 30 January 2020.
Since the outbreak, the Chinese government has provided emergency medical supplies to nearly 130 countries. On April 16, President Xi Jinping published an article titled "Unity and Cooperation is the Most Powerful Weapon for the International Community to Overcome the Epidemic" on the 8th issue of Journal Qiushi. President Xi said that the Chinese government would unite and cooperate with other countries and provide assistance to the countries, who facing the most serious epidemics, in the principle of “Community of shared future for mankind”
Iran is one of the developing countries most affected by the outbreak of COVID-19. The first cases of COVID-19 infections were recognized on February 2020 in Qom city in Iran. Based on the latest official statistics of the Ministry of Health and Medical Education, the total number of patients in Iran with COVID-19 reached to 93,657 people and a number of 5,957 deaths were reported on 30 April 2020. Teheran, the capital of the country is the worst affected region.
As the number of confirmed patients increases in an unexpected speed, the medical waste (MW) generated is far beyond the existing capacity for MW management and disposal. There is a serious lack of medical waste disposal equipment. Due to equipment shortages, hospitals have been forced to increase the number of work cycles which will cause the device to malfunction quickly and further reduce the service life of the device. Furthermore, because of the restrictions imposed by the existing sanctions on the supply of parts for equipment, there is a need to ask the international organizations to provide the safe medical waste treatment equipment for hospitals.
On April 1, 2020, His Excellency Mr. Kazem Gharib Abadi, Ambassador and Permanent Representative of Iran to the United Nations and other International Organizations, sent an official interest letter to Mr. Li Yong, Director General of the United Nations Industrial Development Organization (UNIDO) to request assistance in developing an emergency project to support the medical waste treatment equipment and relevant trainings, which is the country’s priorities to combat against the outbreak of coronavirus.

title.narrative: Response to the COVID-19 crisis through the revitalization of the light industry sector in Armenia

description.narrative:
The COVID-19 pandemic is primarily a global health crisis that has far-reaching economic consequences for each and every country affected by it. Worldwide, it is already disrupting millions of people’s livelihoods, with disproportionate impact across a variety of industries, thereby jeopardizing the successful achievement of national development strategies. Amid the COVID-19 outbreak, the Armenian Government imposed a nationwide lockdown of nonessential businesses, including Textile/Clothing and Footwear/Leather Goods sectors in the second half of March 2020. As of June 2020, following lockdown measures introduced in many countries, including those where major buyers of Armenian Textile/Clothing and Footwear/Leather Goods sectors are based, Armenian producers have lost the majority of their contracts for March and April and are facing unprecedented pressures and uncertainties regarding opportunities to revitalize their businesses in the upcoming months.
In order to address this unprecedented challenge, there is a high demand for an agile and suitable response towards its socio-economic impacts, in particular concerning fragile health infrastructures and their ability to further contain the spread of the virus.
As a response to the above challenges, UNIDO has formulated a light sector support initiative aiming at supporting the Armenian Government in its efforts to prevent further spread of the novel coronavirus and enhance local SMEs’ resilience in a post-epidemic context thereby paving the way to improved flexibility and sustainability of the light industries, as well as poverty reduction. Complementary to the ongoing UNIDO project on "Improving competitiveness of export-oriented industries in Armenia through modernization and market access", the proposed project is expected to produce a supportive impact on the local SMEs operating in the targeted light industries in the times of crisis helping to build a long-term resilience thereof by a) Identifying current needs in medical supplies and technical standards for the production of medical gowns, face masks, overalls, bedlinen and other items in coordination with the Ministry of Health; b) Supporting selected companies with procuring raw materials; c) Supporting the Ministry of Health and other involved institutions in placing orders to companies; d) Ensuring that the production is in line with standards and quality requirements; e) Supporting the provision of medical supplies to the Ministry of Health or other interested national institutions.
The programme will be funded from the UN COVID-19 Response and Recovery Fund, Window 2 “Mitigating the Socio-Economic Impact on Vulnerable People and Communities” within its priority area “Promote digital innovations that boost employment, support livelihoods, and improve the provision of social services in line with COVID-19 response measures”.

title.narrative: Increasing Preparedness for Online Sessions of UNIDO Policymaking Organs

description.narrative:
The global fallout from COVID-19
Following the World Health Organization (WHO)’s declaration of a public health emergency of international concern on 30 January 2020, public health measures aimed at containing the spread of the virus were put in place in an increasing number of countries. As of the WHO’s declaration on 11 March 2020 of a global pandemic, countries in every region of the world have followed suit. The majority of UNIDO’s 170 Member States have instituted some form of public health measures to limit the spread of the virus amongst their populations, and the number of countries restricting the free movement of peoples and goods has grown to cover the world’s major economies and population centres.
As a result of the spread of the virus and the containment measures to combat it, countries around the world are grappling with a significant strain on their health systems, as well as the negative economic and social effects of work stoppages, travel suspensions and supply chain disruptions. In today’s globalized economy, no country in the world can anymore claim to be entirely unaffected by the spread and effects of the COVID-19 pandemic.
Host country restrictions
UNIDO’s host country of Austria has, as one of around 50 countries, instituted a public lockdown, which took effect on 16 March 2020 and lasted around seven weeks. In coordination with the Government of Austria, the United Nations in Vienna imposed health and safety-related measures in line with those issued by the host country. Chief amongst them was the directive for United Nations personnel to work remotely and to limit physical access to the Vienna International Centre (VIC), the location of UNIDO’s headquarters.
An end to measures regulating the size of public gatherings is contingent upon a negative rate of viral replication in the host country. This makes the duration of such measures difficult to accurately predict and plan for. In addition, a second wave of infections and a consequent resumption of containment measures later in the year cannot be ruled out. Information circulated by the inter-organizational Crisis Management Team of the VIC stipulates that in-person meetings and events at the VIC be subject to a cap on the total number of participants and the application of physical distancing measures. Coupled with projected logistical constraints, this considerably limits the ways in which larger meetings can be conducted, at least for the remainder of 2020. As such, it has become necessary to consider alternative means of staging larger gatherings involving representatives of Member States, such as briefings, consultations, working group meetings, governing body sessions and similar events, traditionally held in-person at the VIC.
Member State expectations and United Nations system responses
Member States of United Nations-system entities have during this period expressed their general support for the use of online-conferencing facilities, leading many organizations to rapidly adopt various means to engage with their Member States online at a time when in-person meetings are not advisable or possible in most countries of the world.
A survey by the United Nations Governing Bodies Secretariats (UNGBS) network – an exchange platform which facilitates effective system-wide decision-making by sharing best practices, experiences and guidance – was conducted during the first weeks of March to map the different approaches being considered across the UN system for continued governing body decision-making under the existing physical limitations.
The UNGBS network’s survey results issued on 27 March 2020 showed that of the 19 responding governing body secretariats, excluding UNIDO, eight were already at that point planning to conduct decision-making processes or meetings via online solutions. An additional 12 had at that point either already commenced, or were about to begin, holding consultative meetings of their Member States online.
In the meantime, individual UN organizations in Vienna are opting for online governing body meetings. In a survey of its Member States by the United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime (UNODC) conducted in mid-April 2020, respondents showed a willingness to hold regular sessions of their governing and policymaking bodies (Commission on Narcotic Drugs and Commission on Crime Prevention and Criminal Justice) online, in addition to every other category of meeting or consultation. The question of whether to allow for remote decision-making by its commissions was answered with an overwhelming ‘yes’.
From 4 to 6 May 2020, the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) also headquartered in Vienna held its Programme and Budget Committee (PBC) entirely online. The IAEA’s Board of Governors, in consultation with the Secretariat and with unequivocal support amongst its ranks, decided to hold the PBC, in a streamlined form and a week later than planned, on a remote conferencing platform already in use at the IAEA.
Additionally, the President of the UN General Assembly communicated in a letter dated 23 April 2020 that he has initiated a process to explore the possibility of online decision-making, upon the request of several Member States. Consequently, a series of scenarios and procedures have been developed by UN Secretariat staff, outlining how decision-making by the General Assembly could feasibly be undertaken through online means only.
The conferencing solutions used to date by United Nations system organisations in Vienna have varied greatly. Member State representatives have communicated to UNIDO, and other organisations, their express desire for a unified online conferencing tool for all Vienna-based United Nations organizations.
The situation at UNIDO
Between the start of the containment measures adopted by UNIDO on 16 March 2020 and 1 June 2020, only three formal engagements were held with representatives of Member States. This is of particular note, since the thirty-sixth session of UNIDO’s PBC was to be held on 15 and 16 June 2020, and the period normally leading up to sessions of the PBC are marked by a heavy schedule of regional consultations and meetings of the Informal Working Group on PBC-related issues. In late March 2020, a request by the Policymaking Organs Secretariat of UNIDO to hold online briefings was rejected by the Executive Board in light of the extraordinary situation at the time. As the physical distancing measures continue, it is increasingly clear that UNIDO, as all UN organizations, will have to be able to offer online services to its Member States in the future.
The first formal online meeting of representatives of UNIDO’s Member States took place on 22 April 2020, in the form of a meeting of the Enlarged Bureau of the PBC. The meeting served to determine what course of action to take concerning the upcoming PBC, given that a return to business as usual by its scheduled date could not be assumed.
Feedback from delegates during the meeting oscillated between the options of postponing the PBC to a date later in the year, or holding it entirely online on the originally foreseen dates. Those advocating for an online PBC cited 1) the fact that the schedule of meetings after the summer period – when meetings at the VIC were set to resume – would be unmanageable for all but a few delegations in Vienna, and 2) the understanding that a second postponement necessitated by a resumption of containment measures could not be ruled out.
Ultimately, the decision made by the members of the PBC was to postpone its thirty-sixth session to 29 and 30 September 2020, upon recommendation by the Chair of the thirty-fifth session and the Secretariat. It was however understood by UNIDO’s Member States, as explained by the Secretariat, that preparations for an eventual fully online PMO session would continue as a contingency measure.
The postponement of the PBC to a date later in the year also does not resolve the issue of deferred briefings, consultations and working group meetings, which had been foreseen for the second and third quarter of 2020 and will still be required in the run-up to the PBC and later the IDB.
The primary and immediate reason for UNIDO’s assistance is to provide its Member States with continuity of governance in contexts when it is needed the most. As the COVID-19 pandemic has demonstrated, UNIDO cannot under any circumstances be rendered legislatively inoperational at the precise moment when the global need for its services is at its greatest. Additionally, by modernizing UNIDO’s communications infrastructure with its Member States, the decision-making processes of its policymaking organs will be rendered more efficient and effective.
Constitutionally, UNIDO has three principal organs: the General Conference (GC), the Industrial Development Board (IDB) and the Secretariat. The PBC is a subsidiary organ of the IDB. UNIDO’s current business continuity planning is centred around ensuring that the Secretariat remains functional under adverse external circumstances. As the current context has however made clear, there is an urgent need to it does not give sufficient attention toconsider the new requirements for either the GC, IDB or PBC to be fully functional in such cases and allow a smooth and operational decision making process. This project therefore aims to remedy this gap in planning and ensure that the decision-making integrity of UNIDO’s Member States through its policymaking organs is guaranteed under circumstances when they cannot physically meet.
The objective of the project is therefore to fully develop UNIDO’s capacity to hold full-fledged policymaking organ sessions entirely online, in order to ensure continued governance by its Member States under adverse external circumstances or when expedient.
This straightforward objective seeks to repair a fundamental weakness in terms of the continuity of UNIDO’s governance. This weakness has been exposed by the unprecedented effects of the global COVID-19 pandemic, yet it can also be remedied by the similarly unprecedented sophistication and proliferation of digital technology. Accomplishment of the project’s objective would therefore allow representatives of UNIDO’s Member States to take part in sessions of the Organization’s policymaking organs regardless of their or the Secretariat’s physical location.
The development of UNIDO’s capacity to formally interact with its Member States online is a project which has been foreseen by the Policymaking Organs Secretariat, and which has now been greatly accelerated due to the current circumstances. Therefore, a number of important secondary benefits are expected from the completion of this project. One strategic medium-term benefit to UNIDO is that by staging policymaking organ sessions online, the direct participation of officials from national capitals can be facilitated. This allows for dramatically streamlined decision-making by eliminating the need to relay instructions between Vienna and national capitals. This lag has caused significant slowdowns in the proceedings of recent policymaking organ sessions, most notably the forty-seventh session of the IDB, resulting in the session being suspended and resumed at a later date.
Resumed and special sessions of UNIDO policymaking organs have also been increasing in frequency over the last years. Each time such an unplanned session is held, it results in additional costs for the Organization. Fully developing UNIDO’s capacity to hold online sessions of its policymaking organs would however provide a flexible and inexpensive alternative for resumed and special sessions, which often only deal with one agenda item for which an agreement has already been reached in advance by Member States, and thus merely represent a formality.
Looking ahead to the calendar of highly consequential policymaking organ sessions in 2021 - which will include inter alia complex negotiations for the next biennial budget and an election of a new Director General - is imperative that UNIDO’s capabilities to effectively consult with Member States is enhanced and that more efficient means of decision-making are developed.
Establishing a regularized online mode of interaction with Member States – covering briefings, consultations, working groups and policymaking organ sessions – is also expected to result in additional sustained long-term cost savings. Travel-related costs will form the bulk of the savings. By holding engagements with Member States online, the cost of flying UNIDO field personnel or invited speakers in drops significantly, in line with the Organization’s carbon footprint. Additionally, costs associated with the rental of venues and the hiring of personnel to coordinate and service physical meetings fall away. Established pricing schemes for meetings and conferences at the VIC often result in UNIDO having to pay for resources that it does not end up using.

title.narrative: Emergency livelihood support and job creation to mitigate the socio-economic impact of Covid 19 among internally displaced people and host communities in the Kurdistan Region of Iraq

description.narrative:
The proposed project aims to address the socio-economic impact of COVID-19 among IDPs and host communities in KRI by providing emergency livelihood support and job creation. This will enhance economic resilience, sustainable livelihoods and increase well-being. The project approach is based on harnessing the asset base of the project beneficiaries enabling them to establish sustainable livelihoods. First, is harnessing the human capital, who are the beneficiaries themselves. The project will provide skills and entrepreneurship training to improve their technical skills, acquire entrepreneurial knowledge to start/manage the livelihood/micro enterprise of their choice. The trainings provided under UNIDO’s Entrepreneurship Development Programme is expected to develop personal qualities such as willingness and ability to take initiatives, innovation and creativity, readiness to take calculated risks, self-confidence, resiliency in meeting adversities and ability to collaborate among the target beneficiaries. By learning concepts, such as “save, innovate, invest and grow”, beneficiaries (both IDPs and host communities) will gain the concept and principles of self-help and mutual support, building their social capital while strengthening their livelihood activities. The intervention will contribute to the formation of an entrepreneurial population at the grassroots level and contribute to bottom-up development of a competitive private sector in the longer term.
Kurdistan known to be the ‘bread-basket of Iraq’ and recognizing the agriculture potential of the governorates in the region, technical skills related to agribusiness and agri-processing will be promoted and as per interest and needs of the target beneficiaries. After harnessing the human and social capital, the project will provide physical capital in terms of equipment/asset transfer and infrastructure required for the agribusinesses to be established. To the extent that it will be feasible, access to land for proposed agribusinesses will also be explored together with the government counterpart organization. To meet short-term needs for jobs and cash income in the community, infrastructures to be built will utilize labor from the camp or operational area. The project will organize on-site competency-based technical skills training in areas required for the infrastructure e.g. welding, masonry, plumbing, tiling, etc.
Considering the emergency context and the dire socio-economic condition of IDPs especially in the COVID situation, to ensure self-reliance among IDPs in the camp for additional incomes and/or food support, the project will also introduce the concept of “kitchen gardening” within the outline of agri-business and agro-processing intervention of UNIDO. The project will train the beneficiaries on the technical skills and business side of kitchen gardening. The project will also provide seeds and tools necessary to grow food crops to meet their daily subsistence needs; surplus of which they can sell. The beneficiaries will be provided with the necessary skills and training required to process the surplus crops for value addition based on the available market.

title.narrative: Promoting public health and social resilience against COVID-19 by strengthening the domestic supply chain of personal protective equipment under a circular economy approach

description.narrative:
.The overall objective of the proposed UNIDO project is to promote public health and social resilience against COVID-19 by strengthening the domestic supply chains of Personal Protective Equipment (PPE), disinfectants, and hygiene supplies under Circular Economy approach. This project will tackle the goal through upgrading domestic producers and material suppliers in terms of 1) production capacity, 2) quality, and 3) business resilience & continuity in emergencies by applying the product design for reuse model. The selection of the beneficiary companies will cover both formal and informal businesses and prioritize micro-, small-, and medium enterprises (MSME), which play a pivotal role in Ghana’s economy.
As part of the capacity reinforcement, necessary equipment and technologies for upgrading and enhancing production capacity will be defined and supplied, where necessary, as well as establishing business links to promote new value chain for local material use for greener recovery. It has been experienced during the early stage of COVID-19 that protective supplies were in a serious shortage everywhere, and it caused a significant problem among health workers and institutions. Therefore, the assistance will help the country to obtain the supply capability of those critical medical and sanitary items so that the goods can reach the people, community, and especially health institutions who are in need. Furthermore, taking into account the widespread of products whose quality is low and not fulfilling quality requirements in accordance with international standard, the project will address the enhancement of the product quality by making use of UNIDO’s network and partners of UNIDO Global Quality Standards Programme, including ISO and other quality related authorities.
In addition, an innovative approach of the project is to use plant-based chemicals with antibacterial properties infused into fabrics or threads for facemask and other PPE production, which will contribute to reduce waste generation by applying the reuse model of circular economy practices. These chemicals can also be used for disinfection/hand hygiene products. It will utilize and build upon the achievements from previous projects related to plant-based chemicals implemented by UNIDO in Ghana. Importantly, the project will provide not only short-term assistance for the people, hospitals, and medical institutions, who are currently in need for the improved access to PPE, disinfectants, and hygiene supplies, but its successful implementation will also contribute to medium- and long-term humanitarian development of the country and region by anchoring stable public health and bringing stability to both economic activities and livelihood of the people.

title.narrative: Promoting public health and social resilience against COVID-19 by strengthening the domestic supply chain of personal protective equipment

description.narrative:
The overall objective of the proposed UNIDO project is to promote public health and social resilience against COVID-19 by strengthening the domestic supply chains of Personal Protective Equipment (PPE), disinfectants, and hygiene supplies. This project will build the national capacity of the production through upgrading relevant domestic producers, material suppliers, and relevant public organizations in terms of 1) production capacity, 2) quality, and 3) business resilience & continuity in case of emergency situations. The selected local stakeholders in the target supply chain will receive hands-on capacity building training by the professional trainers designated by UNIDO, based on the initial capacity assessment conducted in the inception phase. The selection of the beneficiary companies will cover both formal and informal businesses and prioritize micro-, small-, and medium enterprises (MSME), which play a pivotal role in Gabon’s economy.
As a part of the capacity reinforcement, necessary equipment for upgrading and enhancing production capacity will be defined and supplied, where necessary. It has been experienced during the early stage of COVID-19 outbreak, that PPE, disinfectants, and hygiene supplies were in a serious shortage everywhere, and it caused a significant problem among health workers and institutions as well as general citizens. Therefore, the assistance will help the country to obtain the supply capability of those critical medical and sanitary items in own country so that the goods can reach the people, community, and especially health institutions who are in need. Furthermore, taking into account the widespread of products whose quality is low and not fulfilling quality requirements in accordance with international standard, the project will address the enhancement of the product quality by making use of UNIDO’s network and partners of UNIDO Global Quality Standards Programme, including ISO and other quality related authorities.
Importantly, the project will provide not only short-term assistance for the people, hospitals, and medical institutions, who are currently in need for the improved access to PPE, disinfectants, and hygiene supplies, but its successful implementation will also contribute to medium- and long-term humanitarian development of the country and region by anchoring stable public health and bringing stability to both economic activities and livelihood of the people, while sustaining employment and sources of livelihood of the people by underpinning the domestic production sector. This is fully in line with the notion of Humanitarian-Development Nexus.
The project encompasses the following outcome and outputs; Outcome1 The domestic supply chain of Personal Protective Equipment (PPE), disinfectants, and hygiene supplies improved in terms of 1) production capacity, 2) quality, and 3) business resilience & continuity in emergency situations Output 1 Evaluation of the domestic supply chain of Personal Protective Equipment (PPE), disinfectants, and hygiene supplies conducted Output 2 Selected local manufacturers (or relevant public organization in the target supply chain) capacitated and upgraded to have improved quantitative and qualitative business capacity Output 3 Emergency business continuity plan developed, based on the ISO or equivalent international guidelines for occupational health and safety management (e.g. ISO/PAS 45005:2020) and awareness towards high-risk infectious respiratory diseases, including COVID-19, raised among the domestic supply chain stakeholders.

title.narrative: UNIDO-ILO Cambodia Industry 4.0 Garment Assessment

description.narrative:
The coronavirus outbreak has slowed down’s Cambodia’s GDP growth and has had severe impacts on its key economic sectors such as garment, footwear and travel goods (GFT) sector. Overall, this sector contributes roughly 60% to manufacturing employment. There are approximately 600 exporting garment factories employing around 750,000 people, and supports roughly 20% of all livelihoods.
COVID-19 has severely affected the supply chains of this sector. From a supply perspective, this pandemic has reduced access to essential inputs from China and exports to their largest markets (Europe and the US) have been curtailed due to closure of retail shops. This is compounded by the EU’s decision to partially withdraw Cambodia’s EBA trade preferences in August.
The UN COVID-19 MPTF has allocated $50,000 to the countries targeted under the first call, including Cambodia. The allocation should support the UN Resident Coordinator (UNRC) in jumpstarting and coordinating the implementation of the UN Framework for Immediate Socio-Economic Response with the RGC and across partners. This includes creating the evidence base to provide a convincing investment case for supporting unfunded priorities and building a pipeline of programmes under the UN Framework.
To create the momentum to successfully roll out the SERP for Cambodia, the UNRC Office's $100,000 is therefore available for immediate preparatory work required to design solutions that contribute to building a pipeline of programmes for the socio-economic response. At least three grants of $33,000 each will be available to support preparatory work for pipeline development such as data collection, impact assessments and thematic analysis that can lead to design of joint programs to implement the priorities of the UN SERP for Cambodia and the RGC economic recovery strategy. For each grant, at least two UN agencies should join with the RGC to explore and design solutions.
UNIDO and ILO successfully pitched an idea and secured a grant of US$ 33,000 from the UNRC's Office. To contribute to the implementation of Pillar 3 and 4 of the SERP, this UNIDO-ILO proposal will contribute to the ongoing efforts to modernize the garment sector through increased digitalization and to give technical support to the implementation of the upcoming Strategy for Cambodia’s Garment, Footwear, and Travel Goods Sector (2020-2025) that planned to be launched soon. This garment sector strategy’s objectives are to continue strengthening human resources for improved productivity; continue improving labour conditions and worker well-being; promote local and foreign investment in high-value addition industry and high value products; attract investment; and foster diversification of the Cambodian exports.
The expected output of this proposal is to conduct an assessment to determine 1) current and projected use of relevant technologies and automated machines and processes in Cambodia to gain an understanding of how the sector is becoming more digitized, and how that would affect production and human resources; and 2) required skills development interventions to reskill employees.
There is a clear need for support to Cambodia's GFT sector to ensure its readiness in taking on increased digitization and use of existing and new technology. Most factories in Cambodia operate on a business model that does not take direct orders but through intermediaries or manufacturing groups at headquarters level outside of Cambodia; hence they have less ownership on investment and business operation decisions (also, the sector is almost entirely foreign direct investment, and operating as ‘cut make trim’ factories); hence don’t get the full value of the orders and are short sighted. Additionally, the garment sector is funded almost entirely by foreign direct investment,
UNIDO and the ILO will collaborate with GMAC (Garment Manufacturers Association in Cambodia), and involve manufacturers and ministries in the assessment process – Ministry of Labour and Vocational Training, Ministry of Economy and Finance, , Ministry of Industry, Science, Technology and Innovation at MPTC/Innovation Center, and Ministry of Commerce as it is crucial to get inputs and their vision of the industry for the next 5-10 years.

title.narrative: Accelerating women#s empowerment for economic resilience and renewal: Post COVID-19 reboot in Armenia

description.narrative: The overall goal of the project is to ensure that women and girls in the most vulnerable and marginalized contexts are empowered and act as agents of change during and in the aftermath of the COVID-19 pandemic in Armenia. Through targeted gender-responsive actions aimed at encouraging active participation and contributions to recovery efforts, the proposed intervention seeks to aid the recovering efforts that will help Armenia build back better. The proposed project adopts a three-pronged approach. First, it assists vulnerable women and girls to benefit from targeted business, digital and STEM skills to improve access to professional competencies. This will be achieved through the delivery of fast-track extension courses for rapid reskilling and upskilling of women and girls living in rural areas. Second, the project will foster a more conducive environment with employment opportunities for vulnerable women affected by the crisis, including through the use of the IDEA approach to address skills mismatches and encourage and support female entrepreneurs. Finally, the project will use an evidence-based approach to target women and adolescent girls at risk of gender-based violence. This project intervention has been prepared in response to the Covid-19 MPTF interim call for proposals issued in August 2020. The project is a joint initiative by UNICEF, UNIDO, UNDP and UN Women informed by the socio-economic Impact Assessment of the COVID-19 Outbreak in Armenian Communities as well as the Rapid Gender Assessment on the Impact of COVID-19 on Women’s and Men’s Lives and Livelihoods in Europe and Central Asia.

title.narrative: Member States Engagement Initiative

description.narrative:
The effective pursuit of UNIDO’s mandate has in recent years been subject to a number of challenges which have resulted in the Organization delivering a greater volume of services in spite of a dwindling pool of regular budgetary resources.
Systematizing and upgrading UNIDO’s mechanisms for engagement with its Member States through the proposed project is thus necessary to better showcase its added value for countries in advancing ISID, stimulate greater engagement in UNIDO’s work amongst its membership, and secure the necessary resources to effectively deliver its global mandate. The proposed approach responds to Member States’ requests made in the Abu Dhabi Declaration, and capitalizes on their continued support for the Organization’s mandate to reach the objectives of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development.
A comprehensive, yet tailored engagement approach, which puts forward the entire array of UNIDO services as applied to global development challenges and national development priorities, provides the means to structure, coordinate and ensure consistency in interactions with Member States to achieve this objective. This is what the Member States Engagement Initiative (MSEI) proposes.
The immediate objective of the MSEI is to ensure Member States remain committed to UNIDO and systematically engage with the Organization on a number of priority themes, including climate change, the Fourth Industrial Revolution, the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) and the Decade of Action, and building back better from COVID-19. The Initiative aims to develop and harness the synergies between UNIDO’s key areas of work, Member States’ development strategies and the global development landscape to strengthen relations with, and expand the membership of, the Organization, thereby increasing its political, technical and financial support to accelerate ISID around the world.
Building on the Organization’s strengths – including its normative role, convening power and technical assistance capacities – the MSEI puts forward an integrated system of (re-)engagement revolving around three interconnected components: • The “Development Dialogues” (Output 1), which are a series of interactive dialogues with Member States, aiming to foster two-way exchanges on ongoing and planned activities to further tailor the Organization’s services in line with countries’ stated interests and needs. • The “Consultative Sessions” (Output 2), which are a new forum for in-depth discussions on selected technical and policy issues to help propel the work of UNIDO and its Member States into intergovernmental processes or bodies of relevance to ISID. • A “Member States relationship management” approach (Output 3), which is a multifaceted stakeholder management methodology to strengthen engagement founded, among others, on the identification of key national stakeholders; the synergies between UNIDO’s work and countries’ relevant priorities, policies and strategies; and the joint elaboration of cooperation roadmaps.
The project foresees the active and coordinated involvement and participation of all relevant UNIDO Directorates and Divisions to maximize efficiency, avoid possible overlaps and harness the potential of each interaction for strengthened Member States support and increased cooperation.
A successful execution of the project will ensure that Member States remain committed to the Organization and systematically engage with it in key focal areas, thereby contributing to securing the delivery of its mandate and helping the proliferation of ISID, in particular in the framework of the 2030 Agenda.

title.narrative: Operationalization of the UNIDO strategic framework for partnering with middle income countries

description.narrative:
The adoption by Member States of a UNIDO strategic framework for partnering with middle-income countries (MICs) at GC.18 through resolution GC.18/Res.9 demonstrated that partnering with MICs is essential to UNIDO’s goal of achieving Inclusive and Sustainable Industrial Development (ISID) globally.
The referred resolution included a request for the Director General to prepare a workplan for the implementation of the strategic framework. At IDB.48 Member States adopted IDB Decision IDB.48/Dec.7 requesting Director General to finalize the work-plan for the operationalization for the UNIDO strategic framework for partnering with MICs “ensuring the inclusion of recovery efforts in the context of the aftermath of the COVID-19 pandemic”.
The mandate arising from IDB.48/Dec.7 comes to reinforce UNIDO’s role as key facilitator of ISID in MICs. This project will operationalize UNIDO´s strategic framework for partnering with middle-income countries by identifying specific measures aimed at accelerating the achievement of ISID and the attainment of SDG-9 in MICs. Such measures include, in addition to the workplan for partnering with MICs, the establishment of regional task forces to define strategic, programmatic, partnership and design investment strategies in MICs, in oordination with the field, together with organization of conferences and events to ensure visibility and global endorsement to these strategies, policies, and visions as reflected in the respective outcome documents.
The operationalization of the UNIDO strategic framework for partnering with MICs will also look at ensuring consistency with the strategy for UNIDO’s activities in Small-Island Developing States (SIDs) or the UNIDO strategy for post-conflict situations. The operationalization of the strategic framework is also expected to rely heavily on the UNIDO policy on South-South and Triangular Industrial Cooperation (DGB/2019/09) as a key means for implementation of the workplan for partnering with MICs. Being a mandate from Member States emanating from IDB Decision IDB.48/Dec.7, it is extremely relevant that the workplan responds to the expectations of countries included in the MICs category (up to 103 UNIDO Member States according to the latest update by the World Bank from June 2020).

title.narrative: Evaluation Work Plan and Budget 2021

description.narrative: The Evaluation Work Plan and provisional budget for the biennium 2020/2021 was approved by the Executive Board on 20 February 2020, shortly before the COVID 19 pandemic started that affected the role out of UNIDO´s planned activities. In accordance with the Charter of the Office of Evaluation and Internal Oversight, paragraph 13 (DGB/2020/11 of 11 December 2020), the EIO evaluation work plan for 2021 was presented to the Oversight Advisory Committee (OAC) during their 6th meeting from 10 to 12 February 2021. The biennial evaluation work plan and provisional budget 2020/2021 has been developed on the basis of an evidence gap analysis and in consultation with senior UNIDO staff. In addition, proposals for evaluations were collected from within the Organization and from Member States’ expressions made in briefings and policymaking meetings. The work plan (WP) at hand proposes strategic evaluations that are linked to UNIDO priorities, specific programmes and horizontal themes and/or that are of relevance to the core organizational functions and strategies. The evaluation work plan updated for 2021 is in line with the EIO Strategy 2020-2024.The evaluation work plan and provisional budget 2020/2021 continues to respond to the provisions of the Lima Declaration1 and the recent Abu Dhabi Declaration2 for UNIDO to report on results in achieving enhanced levels of inclusive and sustainable industrial development and on their development impact. It also provides that the UNIDO evaluation function further contributes to the relevant monitoring and evaluation mechanisms for the follow-up on the operationalization and implementation of ISID and, in particular, SDG-9 and those SDGs to which UNIDO contributes directly under the 2030 agenda.

title.narrative: 2021 oPt Emergency Appeal - Gaza - Emergency Cash Assistance

description.narrative: The global outbreak of COVID-19 is putting further pressure on the already deteriorating socioeconomic situation in Gaza. To mitigate this additional socio-economic hardship, the Agency plans provide a one-off unconditional cash transfer of US$ 40 per person to 45,000 extremely vulnerable Palestine refugees per quarter (with an annual target of 180,000) to help cover their essential needs. Assistance will be provided to the at-risk families identified based on UNRWA’s vulnerability criteria, including households headed by females, households headed by older persons or adolescents, and persons with disabilities. The status of the listed beneficiaries will be further verified by UNRWA relief and social workers.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees in the Near East

title.narrative: 2021 oPt Emergency Appeal - Gaza - Coordination and Management

description.narrative: UNRWA requires additional capacity to reinforce the planning, management, monitoring and evaluation of emergency interventions, ensure the safety and security of staff and refugees and safeguard the neutrality of its facilities. This is vital for the efficient and effective delivery of services and to maintain and further develop capacity to respond to rapid-onset emergencies, including the health and non-health consequences of COVID-19. At the headquarters (HQ) level, the Department of Planning is responsible for the planning and coordination of UNRWA’s emergency response activities. Under the 2021 EA, a senior emergency officer will oversee planning, monitoring and reporting activities. Reporting will be managed through an online results-based monitoring (RBM) system that allows the Agency to track actual results against planned priorities on a quarterly basis, facilitating regular consolidated reporting. UNRWA will also maintain other HQ functions in support of emergency operations, such as data analysis for emergency programmes implemented by the Agency’s Department of Relief and Social Services, and engagement with international human rights mechanisms and other legal support led by the Department of Legal Affairs.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees in the Near East

title.narrative: 2021 oPt Emergency Appeal - Gaza - Education in Emergencies

description.narrative:
UNRWA in Gaza continues to support the education of Palestine Refugee students despite the multiple and protracted crises they continue to face. Responding to the additional challenges of the COVID-19 crisis, the Agency continued to focus on the delivery of its Education in Emergencies (EiE) approach, reconceptualised in five key areas: Continuity of Learning, Psychosocial Support (PSS), Safety and Security – Health and Hygiene issues, Technical Vocational Education Training (TVET), and Monitoring and Evaluation (M&E). The adaptation of the Programme has facilitated the roll-out of an emergency response that considered both pre-existing challenges and the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic.
During the 2020/2021 school year, UNRWA in Gaza continues to provide basic education to 287,000 elementary and preparatory school students. In order to adjust to the challenges created by the COVID-19 pandemic, UNRWA will deliver education through a blended learning approach combining in-classroom learning with learning at home. The Education programme will maintain a flexible approach, applying different learning methodologies based on developments and circumstances on the ground, including through the adoption of full remote learning when needed.
In order to provide quality education amidst increased local transmission of COVID-19 in Gaza, remote learning will be provided using printed self-learning educational materials in addition to textbooks, to ensure that support is provided to all students regardless of their ability to access online material. During the 2020/2021 school year, UNRWA will also aim at providing support classes to students who return to in-person learning in class from quarantine and/or isolation periods. While UNRWA will continue to provide education through remote learning to students in quarantine/isolation, additional support through catch-up classes will be offered upon their return to blended learning.
For as long as the situation allows students to receive in-person education in schools, UNRWA will ensure that enhanced COVID-19 hygiene and health measures are implemented in all premises. These include the continued availability of cleaning materials and the improvement of hand washing facilities
Expenditure

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees in the Near East

title.narrative: 2021 oPt Emergency Appeal - Gaza - Emergency Cash-for-Work

description.narrative: Through its cash-for-work (CfW) intervention, UNRWA will support Palestine refugees in coping with the protracted economic crisis and the shocks caused by the COVID-19 pandemic, contributing to mitigate food insecurity by offering short-term employment opportunities to approximately 21,000 poor Palestine refugees. This translates into more than 2,150,000 workdays generating almost 7,500 full time job equivalents and injecting US$ 26 million into the local economy. The short-term work opportunities will include 15,000 unskilled positions, more than 5,700 skilled positions and around 300 professional positions. UNRWA aims to provide 40 per cent of skilled and professional job opportunities to women, and about 40 per cent of all CfW opportunities will target youth (19 to 29 years of age) to expose them to a workplace experience amidst high levels of unemployment for recent graduates. In 2021, UNRWA will continue to implement enhanced occupational health measures to reduce the risk of COVID-19 transmission. CfW beneficiaries involved in front line work will receive the necessary PPE. UNRWA will also provide all CfW beneficiaries with training on safety measures in the workplace, and will screen candidates for pre-existing medical conditions to ensure they are not placed in positions that could expose them to COVID-19.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees in the Near East

title.narrative: 2021 oPt Emergency Appeal - Gaza - Emergency Health

description.narrative:
Under the 2021 EA, UNRWA will continue to support the health needs of Palestine refugees through its 22 Health Centres (HCs) in Gaza. Essential medicine will be provided to 4,700 poor refugees, while hospitalization support, through referrals to a network of partnered private hospitals, will be offered to more than 3,000 vulnerable refugees who do not have the means to cover the cost of secondary and/or tertiary healthcare. In 2021, UNRWA will continue to implement the measures introduced in 2020 to mitigate the risk of COVID-19 transmission, including the provision and use of PPE for all health staff, the implementation of a triage system at HCs for patients with respiratory symptoms, and the use of telemedicine to reduce foot traffic at HCs. The Agency will also ensure that additional staff are available to implement COVID-19 specific measures and to replace staff who may contract COVID-19 and/or need to isolate. Home delivery of medicine to patients with chronic diseases may be provided if required to patients who need to quarantine or if further lockdowns are imposed.
As part of school health activities, UNRWA will continue medical screenings in schools for children with special needs including those with disabilities, and will provide the necessary assistive devices that vulnerable families are not able to afford otherwise.
Expenditure

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees in the Near East

title.narrative: 2021 oPt Emergency Appeal - Gaza - Mental Health and Psychosocial Support

description.narrative: The COVID-19 pandemic and the measures enforced to mitigate its spread have further heightened the existing social, economic and financial challenges, causing additional stress. In order to ensure that mental health and psychosocial support (MHPSS) support is not disrupted during such difficult times, UNRWA will continue to provide MHPSS services remotely through its Education and Health programmes, by using dedicated helplines and hotlines to ensure that people have access to psychosocial support. The Agency will also ensure that school psychosocial counsellors are deployed to all 278 schools across the Gaza Strip to provide both preventive and responsive psychosocial support to all students. Individual and group counselling will be offered either in UNRWA schools if the situation permits, or through remote counselling in case of a full remote learning scenario and in support of students in home quarantine or isolation. The Agency will also ensure that school psychosocial counsellors are deployed to all 278 schools across the Gaza Strip to provide both preventive and responsive psychosocial support to all students. Mental health and psychosocial support counsellors in the 22 UNRWA health centres will provide in-person support to critical cases identified through qualified UNRWA medical staff.
